speaker: Neil
text: Hello. This is 6 Minute English from BBC Learning English. I’m Neil.

speaker: Rob
text: And I’m Rob.

speaker: Neil
text: Bonjour, Rob! Kon’nichi’wa!

speaker: Rob
text: Excuse me?

speaker: Neil
text: ¡Hola! ¿Cómo estás?

speaker: Rob
text: Oh, OK, I think Neil’s saying ‘hello’ in different languages – French, was it? And then.. Japanese? And… Spanish? Is that right?

speaker: Neil
text: ¡Si, muy bien!

speaker: polyglots
text: The English are famously slow to learn other languages. But it seems that Rob and I - and of course you - our global audience here at 6 Minute English - are good examples of polyglots – people who speak more than one language, sometimes known as 'superlinguists'. People who speak multiple languages benefit from many advantages, as we’ll be hearing in this programme.

speaker: polyglot
text: That word polyglot sounds familiar, Neil. Doesn’t the prefix – poly – mean, ‘many’?

speaker: Neil
text: That’s right, like polygon – a shape with many sides.

speaker: Rob
text: Or polymath – someone who knows many things.

speaker: polyglot
text: And speaking of knowing things, it’s time for my quiz question. The word polyglot comes from Greek and is made up of two parts: poly, which as Rob says, means ‘many’, and ‘glot’. But what does ‘glot’ mean? What is the meaning of the word polyglot? Is it:

speaker: polyglot
text: a) many words?,

speaker: polyglot
text: b) many sounds? or

speaker: polyglot
text: c) many tongues?

speaker: Rob
text: Well, there’s three syllables in ‘polyglot’, Neil, so I reckon it’s b), many sounds.

speaker: polyglot
text: OK, Rob, we’ll find out if that’s right at the end of the programme. But leaving aside the origins of the word, what exactly does being a polyglot involve? British-born polyglot, Richard Simcot speaks eleven languages. Listen to his definition as he speaks to BBC World Service programme, The Documentary:

speaker: polyglotidentifies with sheer
text: A polyglot for me can be anyone who identifies with that term – it’s somebody who learns languages that they don’t necessarily need for their lives, but just out of sheer enjoyment, pleasure or fascination with another language or culture.

speaker: identifying with
text: For Richard, being a polyglot simply means identifying with the idea - feeling that you are similar or closely connected to it.

speaker: sheer sheer
text: He says polyglots learn languages not because they have to, but for the sheer enjoyment, which means, ‘nothing except’ enjoyment. Richard uses the word sheer to emphasise how strong and pure this enjoyment is.

speaker: Rob
text: As well as the pleasure of speaking other languages, polyglots are also better at communicating with others. My favourite quote by South Africa’s first black president, Nelson Mandela, is: "If you talk to a man in a language he understands, that goes to his head. If you talk to him in his language, that goes to his heart."

speaker: soul
text: How inspiring, Rob – I’m lost for words! Here’s another: ‘To have another language is to possess a second soul’.

speaker: soul
text: So language learning is good for the head, heart and soul – a person’s spirit or the part of them which is believed to continue existing after death.

speaker: Neil
text: Yes – and what’s more, language learning is good for the brain too. That’s according to Harvard neuroscientist, Eve Fedorenko.She’s researched the effects of speaking multiple languages on the brains of growing children.

speaker: Rob
text: Eve predicted that multilingual children would have hyperactive language brains. But what she actually found surprised her, as she explains here to BBC World Service’s The Documentary:

speaker: proficiencyefficient.
text: What we found – this is now people who already have proficiency in multiple languages - what we found is that their language regions appear to be smaller, and that was surprising…  and as people get better and better, more automatic at performing the task, the activations shrink, so to speak, over time, it becomes so that you don’t have to use as much brain tissue to do the task as well, so you become more efficient.

speaker: proficiency
text: Eve was testing children who already have language proficiency – the skill and ability to do something, such as speak a language.

speaker: efficient
text: Her surprising discovery was that the language regions of these children’s brains were shrinking – not because their speaking skills were getting worse, but the opposite; as they learned and repeated language patterns, their brain tissue became more efficient – worked quicker and more effectively.

speaker: Neil
text: It’s suggested that this increased efficiency is a result of exposure to different languages.

speaker: Rob
text: So that proves it, Neil: speaking many languages is good for the head, heart, mind and soul!

speaker: Neil
text: You took the words right out of my mouth!

speaker: Rob
text: And speaking of words, what does the ‘glot’ in polyglot actually mean? Was my answer correct?

speaker: Neil
text: Ah, that’s right. In my quiz question I asked you for the meaning of the word ‘polyglot’.

speaker: Rob
text: I said, b) many sounds.

speaker: Neil
text: But in fact the correct answer was c) many tongues. You may be a polyglot, Rob, but you’re not quite a polymath yet!

speaker: polyglot
text: OK, well, let me get my brain tissues working by recapping the vocabulary, starting with polyglot – someone who speaks many languages.

speaker: efficient
text: The language centres in a polyglot’s brain are efficient – theywork quickly and effectively in an organised way.

speaker: Proficiency identify with
text: Proficiency means the skill and ability to do something well. And if you identify with something, you feel you are similar or closely connected to it.

speaker: sheer
text: Polyglots learn languages for the sheer enjoyment of it – a word meaning ‘nothing except‘ which is used to emphasise the strength of feeling.

speaker: soul
text: So speaking many languages is good for mind and soul – a person’s non-physical spirit which some believe to continue after death.

speaker: Neil
text: That’s it for this programme, but to discover more about language learning, including some useful practical tips, check out The Superlinguists series from BBC World Service’s The Documentary!

speaker: Rob
text: Bye for now!

speaker: Neil
text: Bye!
